# National Football League Cheerleading

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

**National Football League Cheerleading** , or simply **NFL Cheerleading** ,
is a professional [cheerleading](/wiki/Cheerleading "Cheerleading")
organization in the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"). 26
of the 32 [NFL](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League")
teams include a cheerleading squad in their
[franchise](/wiki/Professional_sports_league_organization "Professional sports
league organization"). Cheerleaders are a popular attraction that can give a
team more coverage/airtime, popular local support, and increased media image.
In 1954, the [Baltimore Colts](/wiki/Baltimore_Colts_\(1947%E2%80%9350\)
"Baltimore Colts \(1947–50\)") became the first NFL team to have cheerleaders.
They were part of the [Baltimore Colts Marching
Band](/wiki/Baltimore%27s_Marching_Ravens "Baltimore's Marching Ravens").

Most NFL cheerleading squads are a [part-time](/wiki/Part-time_contract "Part-
time contract") job. Often, cheerleaders have completed or are attending a
[university](/wiki/University "University"), and continue on to other careers
after cheering for one to four [seasons](/wiki/Season_\(sports\) "Season
\(sports\)"). The members participate in practice, training camp, games,
appearances, photo shoots, and charity events. Apart from their main duties of
cheering during the football games, the cheerleaders have many other
responsibilities. Nearly every team member is available for appearances at
schools, events, conferences, etc., for a set fee.

An anticipated annual event is the release of each squad's calendar, featuring
members for each month in swimsuits, lingerie, or uniforms.

As well as being a mainstay of American football culture, the cheerleaders are
one of the biggest entertainment groups to regularly perform for the [United
States Armed Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed
Forces") overseas with performances and tours being enlisted by the
[USO](/wiki/United_Service_Organizations "United Service Organizations").
Teams send their [variety show](/wiki/Variety_show "Variety show"), an elite
group of their best members, to perform combination shows of dance, music,
[baton twirling](/wiki/Baton_twirling "Baton twirling"),
[acrobatics](/wiki/Acrobatics "Acrobatics"), [gymnastics](/wiki/Gymnastics
"Gymnastics"), and more. In February 2007, the [Buffalo
Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills "Buffalo Bills") even sent a squad of eight along
with their choreographer into the war zone of Iraq. In 1996, the [San
Francisco 49ers Cheerleaders](/wiki/San_Francisco_Gold_Rush "San Francisco
Gold Rush") and their director helicoptered into the war inflicted country of
Bosnia with the USO and the U.S. Army. The U.S. troops in Korea have been
entertained during the holiday season with the USO's Bob Hope Tour. Over the
years, the tour has featured NFL cheerleaders from the [Dallas
Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys") and the [San Francisco
49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers").

## Cheerleader
competitions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_Football_League_Cheerleading&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Cheerleader competitions")]

The first "Battle of the NFL Cheerleaders" was held in 1979 in Hollywood,
Florida. Two cheerleaders from each cheerleading team compete against other
mini-teams in various athletic events. The events include kayaking, 100 yard
dash, obstacle courses, and other events. The Minnesota Vikings Cheerleaders
took home the title in 1979. In 1980, it was held in Atlantic City, New Jersey
and the Washington Redskinettes were the champions. The winners were Shiona
Baum and Jeannie Fritz, and each received a car as the grand prize. The
competition was resurrected in 2006 by the [NFL Network](/wiki/NFL_Network
"NFL Network"), and was called _[NFL Cheerleader
Playoffs](/wiki/NFL_Cheerleader_Playoffs "NFL Cheerleader Playoffs")._ The
playoffs were taped between July 17 and July 21, 2006 at [Six Flags New
England](/wiki/Six_Flags_New_England "Six Flags New England") in Agawam,
Massachusetts. Two-person teams of cheerleaders from 25 of the NFL's 32 teams
participated in a four-event series of competitions. The first two events
tested the cheerleaders' athletic abilities in events like the 100-yard dash,
kayaking, tandem cycling, and the obstacle course. The third event was a
trivia challenge called "Know Your NFL." The final competition was a one-
minute dance routine, similar to what they normally perform on NFL sidelines.
The San Diego Chargers team (Casie and Shantel) defeated the Atlanta Falcons
and St. Louis Rams squads to win the overall championship. The 3 teams
finished in a three-way tie, with 210 points. The Chargers were declared the
winners based on winning the dance competition.

### Teams without
cheerleaders[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_Football_League_Cheerleading&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Teams without cheerleaders")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Green_Bay_Packers_Cheerleaders.jpg/220px-
Green_Bay_Packers_Cheerleaders.jpg)](/wiki/File:Green_Bay_Packers_Cheerleaders.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Green_Bay_Packers_Cheerleaders.jpg "Enlarge")

The Packers collegiate squad in 2009

As of 2016, six teams do not have cheerleading squads: [Buffalo
Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills "Buffalo Bills"), [Chicago
Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago Bears"), [Cleveland
Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns"), [Green Bay
Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers"), [New York
Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants"), and the [Pittsburgh
Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers"). The Packers do,
however, use a collegiate squad to cheer at home games.[19] [Super Bowl
XLV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV "Super Bowl XLV") between the Steelers and the
Packers in February 2011 was the first time a Super Bowl featured no
cheerleaders. The Browns and the Giants are the only NFL teams that have never
had cheerleaders, while the other aforementioned teams have had cheer squads
in the past.

The Buffalo Bills endorsed the officially independent [Buffalo
Jills](/wiki/Buffalo_Jills "Buffalo Jills") from 1966 to 2013; when several
cheerleaders sued both the Jills and the Bills organizations, the Jills
suspended operations.[20]

Teams of "unofficial" cheerleaders began emerging in 2010 for NFL teams that
don't have their own dance squad. These unofficial cheerleaders aren't
sanctioned by the NFL or any franchise in the NFL and therefore are not
allowed to perform at games, represent the football team at any outside
functions, or use any of the team's branding or trademarked colors on their
uniforms. The teams are sponsored by local businesses, and the cheerleaders
perform prior to the game, at tailgate parties, and other local events. Some
also attend the local NFL games in uniform, and sit together in their block of
season ticket seats. Their audition process, costuming, and choreography are
very similar to official NFL cheer teams. Some also produce an annual swimsuit
calendar, just like the legitimate cheerleaders. All of the independent teams
hope at some point to be embraced by the NFL as "official" cheerleaders of
their local teams.

  * The Detroit Pride Cheerleaders were the first independent professional team, put together in August 2010 to support the Lions.[21] However, as the squad was not officially recognized by the Lions, it could not use the Lions' logos nor colors.[22] In 2016, the Lions started an official cheerleading squad.
  * The Gotham City Cheerleaders were organized in August 2011 to support all New York sports, but are most closely associated with the Giants. The team has also been known as the New York Unofficials, the Unofficial Dancers of the New York Giants, and the Gotham’s Team Blue Army Dancers.[23]
  * The Cleveland Spirit Cheerleaders were created in September 2012 to support the Browns as a test team to attract fan interest.[22] This cheer team was created by the same people responsible for the Detroit Pride.[24]

## Pro
Bowl[[edit](/w/index.php?title=National_Football_League_Cheerleading&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Pro Bowl")]

A top honor for an NFL Cheerleader is to be selected as a [Pro
Bowl](/wiki/Pro_Bowl "Pro Bowl") Cheerleader. The group is composed of an all-
star cheerleader (one from each NFL cheer team) that represents her NFL team
at the Pro Bowl in Hawaii. The Pro Bowl Cheerleaders were founded in 1992 and
directed by [Jay Howarth](/w/index.php?title=Jay_Howarth&action=edit&redlink=1
"Jay Howarth \(page does not exist\)") and [Angela King-
Twitero](/wiki/Angela_King-Twitero "Angela King-Twitero"). Each year, one
squad member from every NFL team is chosen to participate in the collective
Pro Bowl cheerleading squad.[25]
